author: g11tech
content:
ok so if i crystallize discussion what can/should be acceptable to all parties:

1. 3 repos, one for core, one for erc and the merged one  for editor's
2. core and erc repos have their own draft acceptance ruleset (with shared numbering system)
3. all changes in  core and erc repos are upstreamed by bots/workflows to editor's repo via auto PRs 
4. post drafts core and erc repo also applies editor's ruleset for PR acceptance - this way authros will never have to hop across different repos and can just work/focus/track their repos
5. editor's repo publishes to the eip url
6. core/erc editors are seeded to the editors of the core and erc repo respectively

author: rudolf6
content:
To add a slightly different version of <@792822129019584562>‚Äôs suggestion above.. It sounds like a variation that might achieve most of what everyone wants is:

1. Fork out ERCs, so there are two repos total (as in Lightclient‚Äôs PR)

2. ‚ÄúEIP editors‚Äù and ‚ÄúERC editors‚Äù are both made part of a larger ‚Äúethereum editors‚Äù group (using placeholder names). This can be under a 3rd repo such as Tim suggested (editors-pm or EIPIP)?

So after the split is done, there is a single ‚Äúumbrella‚Äù editor organization that all editors are a part of. This mitigates Greg‚Äôs concern:
> When the split is done will there remain a single Editor organization responsible for both EIP and ERCs?

But also allows for things like unique lists of editors on each side, and supports other ways the repos may need to diverge, while still maintaining some unification for editors themselves and the editing process across all repos. (Since these should be mostly transparent to core devs anyways, and policies around spelling, grammar, link rules etc can be the same across both repos?) 

This would also address Danno‚Äôs concern of:
> We need to adopt the ACD workflow (draft/EFI/CFI/devnet/testnet/final) as well as adding ‚Äúfork‚Äù metadata flags on the ACD side. Changes which are meaningless to the ERC side.

But I‚Äôm neither an editor nor a core dev. This is just my 3rd party (and possibly naive) take üòõ

author: _shemnon
content: One concern about the "third" editor group by a core dev (not me, but I support) is that it would make it hierarchical. i.e. there should be no power over ERC or EIP editors or authors from this third group. If this can be done without a third group I think it would be an easier sell to ACDC and ACDE.

author: rudolf6
content:
That‚Äôs very fair. Is the concern that EIP editors would have some amount of ‚Äúcontrol‚Äù over ERC editors, and vice versa? 

If so, perhaps that need not be a bad thing if the roles/responsibilities of all editors are scoped appropriately? (E.g. EIP/ERC editors agreeing on shared rules around grammar/links/etc)

Fwiw, rather than a *hierarchical* 3rd group (that sits above the other 2 groups), I view the 3rd group as more of a *unifying* group that simply brings the EIP and ERC editors together for coordination/communication purposes. The 2 editor groups could choose to operate as independently or collaboratively as they see fit within that structure.

(But I‚Äôm also a non-editor sitting here assuming this setup would make sense to the editors)
